Praefatio.	Introduction.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I have finished your book of surgery and its supplementary material concerning the culmination point in medical science through Albucasis' eyes as well as their declarations about it, all has been done to complete this very tract on operations with hand (i.e., chirurgery).
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since the operation with hand (chirurgery) is established in our land and at this time alone: until perhaps it perishes as a science due to lack of study; its examination ceases altogether: so that nothing remains from those times except some incomplete descriptions found among ancient books, which had been corrected by hands—and errors occurred because they did not know the subject well enough. Thus has been explained this very tract on operations with hand (i.e., surgery), and I will complete it in accordance to my time of life: so that we may learn together from these words following formulated thoughts, abbreviations; when coming at last unitedly for cauterizing burns or treating wounds using remaining tools—based on what has been said regarding this subject by Albucasis.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	Because for the reason that at this time not a good artist of hand (surgery) is found to accompany his art with it in our age: as surgery itself has grown long and requires an author well-versed in physiology, which Galenus narrated until he knew exactly how each member works—including its forms, connections, separations; also understanding of the bones, muscles, and blood vessels (and their number), and exits from them as to outward things.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And because of this reason that Hippocrates said: the name is much but with work little and particularly for hand (surgery). This has been stated by Albucasis himself as recorded on his own authority through what he writes, having observed it personally while treating patients.   
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have already discussed this subject at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Since anyone who is not knowledgeable about anatomy as we have discussed it in this book will be untrained and may fall into error from which men are destroyed: I myself witnessed many of these people form themselves on the basis of that science, without any such science or experiment.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	That which happened because I saw a foolish physician follow the apostome scrophulousum into the neck of a woman and cut some arteries in her chest: blood flowed out from her body until she died between his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I saw another physician who presumes to remove stone from the body of an old person and takes out stones that are large:
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	So he went after him and took something with a lance-shaped wound away from him. (The original Latin text here is ambiguous as it can also mean that the physician treated someone who had been stabbed.)
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	And so he died on the third day: This phrase appears to conclude a medical case report, likely detailing an unfortunate outcome of a treatment or
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I too have now called for it to be removed: and because of the size of the stone and its position in a sick person which would lead to death. (The original Latin text here suggests that both physicians saw something requiring removal—possibly stones or foreign objects within patients—due to their detrimental impact.)
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another physician who accepted the fee from some of our landlords because of medicine: and an African eunuch was there with wounds near his heel; a fracture which had occurred in his foot close to the calcaneum (heel bone): and while ignorant of these things, did apply bandages over it wrapped around hot peppers. He also strangled this man's pulse when trying to stop bleeding with cold water poured into pigeon droppings as an absurd treatment method likely influenced by local beliefs or folk remedies rather than evidence-based medicine. The original text paints a picture of the careless and potentially harmful treatments that were attempted on this eunuch, highlighting practices that deviate significantly from modern standards of medical ethics and science. It's illustrative of how cultural influences could impact treatment approaches in medieval times. This translation brings to light not just medical conditions but also attitudes toward healing and the integration of unproven or even harmful methods into patient care during this period, reflecting a broader historical context where such practices might have been more commonplace due
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he proceeded according to his own judgment.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	After that he left him for a few days and forbade the binding of his leg: and so it remained until the stroke had paralysed its limbs, and eventually led to his ruin.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I therefore called for him: and I treated the swelling with heat until he was relieved of his pain.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	Nevertheless, there had been a worsening of the condition within that limb and I could not stop it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore he ceased to walk about with that injury until its end came.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another doctor who punctured the ganglionic tumor; and after a day it was sore but soon became cunning with his lordship until he gained favor.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	That is so because when a pure cancer arises from malignant melancholy at that time it does not need to endure with him entirely; unless he has the limb which accepts such affliction and can lose itself in due course, as if discarding its entirety.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And therefore because of Him your children you must know that the surgery with hand is divided into two parts; one where there is health as well and another involving risk due to multiple displacements.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I am now stirred up wherever this book on surgery comes into view because it contains fear and apprehension.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore it is necessary for you to flee that and abstain from this: so as not to learn the game of strutting with words without substance or deceitfulness.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Take then measure with care and protection; support our infirmities easily but firmly so that we may walk more blessed on the road to salvation through God's grace, leaving us relief from terrible illnesses difficult for cure: thus freeing our spirits of whatever makes you fearful, enabling them to come forth above your hesitation in faith and convenience.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	Foremost it remains for more glory to clothe oneself with humility and elevate itself above the world; ultimately achieving harmony with one's own body measures.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	For Galen, then he had said some of these things before him as well.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not cure evil diseases with ill doctors: avoid their name for good reason.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	This tractate is divided into three chapters now. 
Capitulum primum.	Chapter first. The contents and subject matter of this chapter shall be presented
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Chapter first on cautery with fire and sharp instruments; as well as the use of medicinal acute points for the same purpose within a treatise ranging from head to feet, describing various tools and materials necessary for such operations.: The essentials needed throughout this process shall be included. 
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter second: [Details of Chapter Two's subject matter are expected in a
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Chapter second on excision and perforation; phlebotomy (bleeding for medicinal purposes); lacerations as well as punctures from projectiles like arrows or similar objects: also extraction of such items, along with the rest of this chapter organized by form. 
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter third is anticipated to cover additional surgical topics not explicitly mentioned here but
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	Chapter third on restoration and reduction of joint displacement; as well as curing twisted situations (twists) with the remainder of this chapter covering everything from head to feet in terms of methods and necessary instruments.: The essentials needed throughout these processes shall be included. 
Soli Deo Gloria.	For God's glory alone. 
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Book of Surgeon Albucasis. 
Pars I.	Part One. 
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	In this section concerning the application of cautery and its potential to create nicks or harmful effects; it will also discuss how certain skin conditions may relate to such interventions and when they might occur as well as whether metal (like iron) or gold should be used for these procedures.
Caput I.	Chapter One: [Details of Chapter One's
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	Chapter One but Firstly we should remember the nature of such operations; particularly highlighting aspects like bleeding (Juuement) and wounding effects due to them as well as under what conditions one might expect these outcomes, all while providing examples when necessary.: The essentials needed throughout this discussion shall be included. 
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore that the speech concerning the quality of cautery and its harm is a lengthy, subtle science, which is hidden knowledge.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Also spoken was there among the learned many on it, and they argued about it: and to me indeed suffices little from their speeches; I fear lengthening of discourse.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say therefore that cautery furnishes universally for all kinds of illnesses which are with material and without: excepting two cases - hot sickness notwithterminal nor cold; a dry heat not terminal neither absent from the matter, and a likewise cool one.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	Moreover in heated-cold with or without material they also disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some indeed said that cautery is suitable for those things as well.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others opposed them in this way; namely that cautery is not suitable for illnesses which are from hot and dry conditions: because nature itself is heat - as the saying goes 'nature abhorrs a vacuum'; so it follows-that being healed of such an affliction, made worse by warmth or drought (and this despite its own natural tendency to be relieved in these ways), can not truly recover health.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who said the contrary thereof; namely that by cautery is done iuvenation for all illnesses which are hot and dry-which happen to our bodies: when you compare body of man with its humours, if it be compared in relation to heat - then likened will you find his natural state cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I, indeed, affirm by the speech of him himself; for he has already left that matter to me some times over.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	Nevertheless it would be unsuitable for that matter to come before me unless he who has now already proven himself and is practised in the art of cauterization (and knowing well both differences among human complexions as regards disease, illness itself within us, causes thereof, consequences therefrom-accidents too - space also), all which I have previously spoken.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	At those points then his fear for bodily wounds is not felt at all, especially with regard to colds and dampness.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	Indeed, all physicians agreed upon this matter, especially regarding the cautery; and they did not disagree with its use therein.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And he knew his son' endured treatment by Cautery with fire and that its quality over the burning medicine was good; for it is simple in action which does not arrive at body unless applied to a part cauterised: but hurts other members only if done unto the skin.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The burning action of medicine certainly reached this point that it extends from the members; and perhaps even causes death to occur at difficult diseases: probably kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire therefore because of its subtlety and goodness does not do this unless it is in excess.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Indeed now we realize that this was due to the weakness of our instruments and studies in medicine; and being situated over the truths of things, thus causing us to be excluded from such lengthy discourses about fire as are unnecessary for its use hereinabove mentioned: therefore excused by it.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if not for the fact that this book does not permit me to discover from fire within it an occult secret; and its quality of operation in expelling diseases is as shown by philosophy's learned demonstration which will quiet philosophical minds, I would bring you back what has been concealed thus far.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And he knew his son that they themselves disagree about the time when it is convenient to perform Cautery; and preferring better times for speaking let this be left then as before mentioned hereinabove: therefore excused by its lengthiness also, because of which reason we have not yet said anything else.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	I declare that Cautery is suitable at all times; because the harm resulting from it due to its being immersed comes into agreement with what has been said before mentioned hereinabove: therefore excused by this lengthiness too, as well for which reason we have not yet added anything else.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	Especially if the cauterium is due to painful conditions necessary for medical reasons, urgency or haste: therefore that it happens which may be a greater harm than mere physical injury because of time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	But let it not fall into the minds of those who are unconvinced unless they consult foolish or ignorant physicians: and mark this consequence, which is different from what people think: for that cauterium does not occur except in places related to medicine, since one thing alters complexion and another removes humidity, which are causes of pain.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	But then the operation exceeds medicine and virtue of itself, and with earnest command from its master: and it is possible that he returns to health for some time according to the condition of his body, the location of disease, and his character or virtues: and what prepared within him comes out into this in food and drink (and other things like causes), unless a sickness arises which requires cauterium.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	A sickness of delicate nature arises under slight inflammation and humidity, like the pain caused by cauterium used for teeth: it is possible that he does not return to health from this suffering.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But such things are of short duration.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But truly there is another time to speak about this thing which the knife is at last medicine and not harm: for they believe that it does no healing or aid given by medicine itself with its own treatment nor after other treatments like incision have been done, contrary to what people intend in saying such things.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But on the contrary to this opinion is that which I have said before: and it has an aim not unless when we administer modes of cure in some disease, and do not give them any medical treatment: then finally we treat with medicine itself, and confer: so at last falls what was called post-remedies by physicians. Thus the knife is considered as a final resort for healing only after all other methods have failed to produce their desired effects on people considering such things foolish or absurd utterances of ignorant rhetoricals in medicine, and multistolid wicked doctors who understand nothing but how much harm they cause.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	They said that the scalpel with gold is better than one with iron and they did not say so except for its equality to silver and solidity of substance itself; and they claimed it does not produce a place where abscesses form.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But that is not true: for I have already tried it and found that this does not make such things without others in some corpses.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And they said the scalpel with silver is good itself and better than iron for it as well.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	But when you use fire for the scalpel in silver taken from gold as they say is good and better than iron itself; it does not declare to me that which happens if I light according to amount of fuel used because of tarnishing with gold: And, being suitable for coldness once ignited upon a wound over an incision by burning metal (as was done), liquefies in fire and rolls into layers.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Why does the artist fall from this into employment? And because of that reason it is fitting for a scalpel with iron to be used at our place and more suitable in respect to honesty towards operations.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I have already arranged this chapter on the scalpel according to chapters for times sake, and from head to foot as in books till those seeking ask of that which they will do with it: so ordering shall be done towards them desiring knowledge about such things..
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	Regarding the method for using a lancet at the temple joint.
Caput II.	Part two, concerning the head..
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	This part focuses on the proper cauterization technique at the temple joint for controlling moisture and coldness over the brain; which are two causes of hiccups as stated by Socrates, along with various flows of humors from the head to parts of the eyes and ears caused by an excessive number of people. Universal diseases that occur due to a chill include paralysis, epilepsy, apoplexy, among others; all which are similar in nature..
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The mode of cauterization is to start with healing the sick: first applying medicine in a world-cleansing manner for three or four nights based on what demands from weak people according to their age and habitus.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Thereafter command him to cauterize his own head with a new needle.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then have him sit between your four-square hands, as he has already placed his hands over his chest. This instruction is a continuation of the cauterization process in medieval Latin tradition where specific postures and hand positions were crucial for surgical procedures like cataract extraction or treating abscesses through
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the back of your hand over his nose'in between their eyes, as he has already done so with respect to his own hands above his chest in a specific surgical technique during cauterization. This procedure aligns closely related anatomy and follows previous steps for maintain
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Therefore when your middle finger touches it marks the spot with fire as a guide during cauterization, continuing with this precise local anesthesia and thermal mark technique used to minimize pain for patients undergoing surgery without general sedation at that time in medieval history.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Thereafter perform the cauterization with oil as follows, which was a common practice and technique during this era for treating wounds or removing unwanted tissue through controlled application of heat in conjunction with
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	After placing the patient on a marked spot cauterized by fire and downsizing for descent into position where your hand gently but firmly compresses it to control bleeding as he is assisted back up; this step involves continuous monitoring of vital signs which was essential during surgical procedures before modern anesthetics were available. The technique described ensures both the effectiveness in stopping blood flow and

The touch should be applied by your own hand in gentle compression until something liquidy comes out when you listen carefully: and this heated thing, now cooler due to less heat iron (i.e., copper), is warmed internally; it no longer emits that which distills into cold wax at the end of these drugs' administration because medicine does not tolerate such a phenomenon.

Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos. ¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the drawing of blood from suckling goats: if a person should be unable for any reason, let him not do it
Caput XXXIX.	Head thirty-nine.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the treatment of suckling goat blood is done as divided into courses with medicine; if it cannot be performed at that time: then consider a person who has weakness in his chest, sitting or standing before the sun (or god), after he had spoken their language and touched him using an instrument mentioned by me.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If then your custom falls upon the suckling goat: remove it with a dung beetle in mid-day (or by moonlight): or using deft hands to handle small stones underground near its abode, wherein I've previously described this practice. This is according to what has been recorded here and now presented for the first time from my personal experience:
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	What if it is not possible with them? Then take a softened gut from the inside of its shell and insert that into their chest as far forward towards his mouth: then thrust in the heated iron rod which has been wetted, deep within until near to where I previously instructed. This practice derives solely based on my own experience without prior documentation before this point now being presented for first time public record by me myself personally.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do that often, and keep the weak one away from water throughout the day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Thereafter receive the goat into cold water and open its mouth within it; then mix together with this water his own saliva to create a mixture, so that he does not swallow anything from there: after which allow him to drink some more hot water for one hour later on using only their hand. This method is based purely upon my personal experience without prior documentation before I now present the first time public record of myself personally.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	Bloodsuckers fall in when they feel water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	If the ill one does not exit when I tell what we have been narrating, then he will be chilled with biting insects or stung by ants, and scorched with a burning instrument during suffocation.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do that often because she falls in (or is overcome).
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation (suffumigation) is such that you take a pot with burning olive oil inside, and have it covered with clay; into which there should be an opening through which instruments can enter at one end: in this way, healing tools are inserted.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Thereafter throw out the suffumigation and put a cannula in his mouth at one end: shut his own mouth so that he does not leave (suffumigation). Continue until you realize what suffumigation has already led to bloodsucking.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	Because a vampire bat falls immediately.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	But if he does not fall in (suffumigates), then repeatedly throw out the suffumigation and do this often.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And he will bear it (pain) patiently; let him eat vinegar as well as black pepper and salt but not water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore, so that one departs with this regime in mind.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of a tool or device to remove bloodsuckers from his mouth when he falls in with their bite.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is like fingernails, as you see them; unless these are hurdles imposed upon his throat (by the bites).
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And his end is like that of a vulture with its beak (which has rough edges): when it finds something to eat, it does not let go at all.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	On the opening and care of wounds generally; with their parts and general treatment.
Caput XL.	Head Chapter 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many apoplectic species, of various kinds as recorded by one individual; and they differ greatly in their appearance for puncture or incision—they come in two distinct methods detailed herein: cutting into halves with the scalpel's edge held horizontally.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One species of apoplectic is endemic to itself and understandable through moisture conditions; it thrives within a damp environment which sustains its unique characteristics required for the understanding provided in this textbook on medieval surgery, as penned by Albucasis.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore. Since an apoplectic affectation occurs within the head, it is different from that occurring within the rectum; and since a localized swelling or hardness in the flesh results when affected by an apoplectic condition at specific joints—this too requires its own judgment based on surgical intervention as articulated herein.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum. Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	Indeed, what remains from the wound continues to harm what is left of it.

Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And there are some such abscesses within the head of certain people with whom repentance is not possible due to a lack of moisture.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	That is: because I have cut the beard of a woman to remove an abscess in her head that was as solid and hard as stone; and if struck against another person with such force while projecting blood from it, he gets wounded too.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis. ¶ De extractione Lapidis.	On taking out the stone (lithotripsy).

Deinde accipe lanam, et submerge in succo tarathit, aut succo arnoglossae, aut succo ramorum alaulat, id est, aglanter, uino pontico, et fac adhaerere loeo.	Then take some wool (accipe lanam), and immerse it in a mixture of tarate juice (succo tarathit) or tongue-spur spurge sap (succo argloglossae)...or hazelwood sap...that is, aglacteric vinegar (agranter uino pontico)…and make sure his wound be covered with it.
Cum ergo quiescit apostema, tunc cura locum cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	When then the ulcer ceases to hurt: then take care of its place (locum), and apply ointments on it until healed...(donec sanetur).
Albarth uero rubeum est simile capitibus alhaasse, et est asperi aspectus.	However the red berries of barberry (albahart) are similar to hazelnuts in form and have a rough appearance...(est asperi aspectus).
Oportet ergo ut incidas quod apparet ex eo, secundum quod dixi in thelil aequaliter: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Therefore it is necessary that they wear what appears to come from him (quod apparit ex eo), according to this saying which I told you...(eundec sanetur).

¶ Doctrinae Obstetricum, qualiter medicentur embriones uiui, secundum figuram non naturalem egressi.	The "Doctrine of Midwifery," in which they care for embryos as if their departure from nature were illustrated by a figure and not natural form alone.
Caput Lxxu.	Head page LXX.
Necesse est Obstetrici, ut cognoscat in primis figuram partus naturalis.	It is necessary for obstetricians to understand at first the figure of a natural birth process.
Ex signis ergo eius est, quod quando uides mulierem comprimi ad inferiora, et desiderat odorare aerem, et alleuiatur super eam quod super ipsam est de partu, et festinat exitus embrionis: tunc scias quod iste partus est secundum figuram naturalem, et est exitus eius super caput suum, et secundina cum eo: aut suspensa, uel pendens ex umbilico.	Therefore he (the embryo) must know that which happens when you see a woman being pressed toward the lower part of her body and desire to smell air over it; above this is where birth has taken place on its own, with or without contractions: at such time then one knows whether this delivery process follows natural appearance in form, and if so occurs after childbirth. It happens when thereafter a second period succeeds the first as naturally likewise (within her head), either uprightly above it or suspended from its navel-line (umbilicus).
Cum ergo uides haec signa, tunc oportet ut comprimatur uenter eius, ut descendat embrio uelociter.	When you have observed these signs, then it is necessary that he should be quickly compressed to his belly so the embryo descends properly.
Nam quando descendit super caput suum, descendit secundina cum eo, et mundatur ex illis superfluitatibus mundificatione bona.	When it has descended above its head, then also it will come down secondarily to his head and with good manners the world is cleaned from these excesses.
Qui autem est praeter hunc partum, est innaturalis, illaudabilis.	But he who remains outside of this time [of gestation], it's unnatural and blasphemed.
Quoniam quandoque egreditur foetus super pedes suos, et egreditur corpus eius ante caput ipsius, et pedes eius, et manus eius una, aut pes eius unus: aut egreditur caput eius et manus eius: aut egreditur uentrinus: et fortasse conuertitur super collum suum, et similia ex figuris illaudabilibus.	When then the fetus emerges out of his legs and his body comes forth before its head, and his feet or one foot only; or maybe when it has come forth with just its hands: Or perhaps he will take his head and arms first: And even more likely to turn on their own backs as in images which are blasphemous.
Necesse est ergo Obstetrici, ut sit prudens, subtilis in istis rebus omnibus, et caueat sibi ab errore et decaeptione: et ego sum ostendens omnem figuram ex eis, et qualiter est ingenium in ea, et significetur per illud, et stetur super ipsum.	Therefore it is necessary for Obstetricians to be prudent and subtle about all things: And let them guard themselves against error and deception; I am showing you every shape taken by this embryo in these images: and how clever his mind can appear, as shown through that image itself. It stands firm on its own representation.
Quando egreditur foetus super caput suum egressione sua naturali, et uehemens fit illud super mulierem, et difficilis fit ei partus, et uides uirtutem eius iam debilitatam: tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, aut mulieres teneant eam: et uapora uuluam eius cum foenugraeco decocto, et cum oleis humidis.	When then the fetus emerges out of its head with natural birth and forces it upon womankind; indeed an easy part for her to bear: but you have already seen how feeble his virtue has become by this time: let him sit on a chair, or women may hold him: apply oil heated in grape juice mixed with olive oil.
Deinde intromittat Obstetrix inter digitos suos Spatumile paruum, et findat cum eo secundinam, et secet eam ungue suo, donec currat quod est in ea ex humiditate: et preme uentrem mulieris, donec descendat foetus.	Thereafter the Obstetrician introduces a sponge between his fingers called Spathula parva; and when he finds it with him [the fetus], apply to its own finger until that which is in liquidity drips out: then press on the woman's womb, so as for the child to descend.
Si autem non descendit, tunc oportet ut clisterizetur mulier ex mucillagine foenugraeci, cum oleo sisamino.	But if it does not descend at that time [after massage with sponge], then he must give the woman a laxative enema made of fenugreek seed in honeyed oil.
Deinde praecipe ei post clistere, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi, et tene os eius et nasum ipsius hora una.	Now command him to cough it out after the enema and hold his breath with one hand on his head and nose at once.
Foetus enim egredietur statim.	The fetus is immediately born forth.
Quod si egrediantur duae manus foetus in primis, iunc oportet ut reducas eas cum facilitate paulatim.	If they are to come out with two hands first, it must be that you bring them back gradually and easily.
Si autem non obedit in introitu, tunc pone mulierem super sedem, et eleua pedes eius sursum: deinde concute sedem super terram: et mulier teneatur, ut non cadat apud concussionem. ¶ De curatione Fistularum quae accidunt in inferiori parte.	Concerning the treatment of fistulas occurring in the lower part.
Caput LXXX.	Head eighty.
Fistulae quae accidunt in inferiori, sunt Nodatio, et Grossitudo quae accidunt prope anum deforis: aut in spacio unius partium: et est Fistula una, aut plures.	Fistulas occurring in the lower parts are nodulosis and enlargement that occur near ground level or at a certain height within a given space; they are one kind of fistula, but there can be more kinds.
Cum ergo antiquatur illa Nodatio, aperitur, et currit ex ea humiditas aquosa alba, aut pus subtile.	So it must then that such old nodulosis opens and runs out of the wetness with white water or faint pus.
Et quandoque sunt ex istis Fistulis penetrantes.	And whenever these fistulas pierce through them.
Ergo penetrantes cognoscuntur per illud quod egreditur ex egestione, et uentositate, quando utitur infirmus egestione: et fortasse egreditur ex eis uermis.	So they are recognized through that which comes out with evacuation or drainage when used for weak elimination; and perhaps it also escapes by coughing.
Et sunt ex eis Fistulae quando sunt in spacio penetrantes usque ad uesicam, et usque ad meatum uirgae.	And they are fistulas when contained within that space and extending to the point of being drained out or flowing as far upward as a nasal cavity.
Et sunt ex eis penetrantes usque ad iuncturam coxae, et usque ad nodum caudae.	And they are fistulas when contained within that space and extending to the joint of the hip or even as far downward as a tailbone node.
Ex eo autem quo cognoscitur Fistula penetrans usque ad anum, etiam a non penetrante, est, ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum: et intromittas tentam subtilem in Fistulam ex aere, aut ferro: quando non est tortuositas.	And it is known as fistula penetrating up to the navel; and even if there isn't such piercing through which passage exists from an intact or open one - for instance inserting your own finger into a belly button – when not tortuous, it can be inserted with fine wires made of metal.
Quod si in ea est tortuositas, tunc intromitte in eam tentam ex plumbo subtilem, aut pilum ex pilis equarum, donec sentias tentam, aut pilum in digito tuo.	And if it is so that there exists such tortuosity within them - then insert a thin wire made of lead or iron into the fistula until you feel for this wire, or till you find an arrowhead lodged in your finger as provided by arrows drawn on horseshoes.
Quod si non sentis ipsam penitus, neque procedit ex foramine aliquid ex egestione, neque uentositas, neque uermis sicut dixi: tunc scias, quia est non penetrans: propera ergo ad curationem.	And if you do not feel that way forthrightly - nor does any substance come out with evacuation or drainage as I have described; neither by urination nor through a discharge, and certainly no pus is produced – then you know this is non-penetrant: accordingly it should be directed to cure.
Et quando Fistula est penetrans usque ad uesicam, aut ad meatum urinae: tunc significatio eius est exitus urinae ex ea, et prohibitio eius ab hoc ut consolidetur locus cum medicinis.	And when a fistula is penetrating until it reaches the urethra or bladder: then that signifies an outflow of urine from there and its prevention by this so as to solidify the location with medicine.
Si uero est penetrans usque ad iuncturam coxae, aut ad os coxae: tunc signum eius est, quod perueniat tenta usque illuc, si non est in ea tortuositas usque ad os: et inuentio doloris in circumitu partis, et quod egreditur pus ex ea semper: et quod non ualeat in ea medicatio, neque consolidatur cum unguento.	If it is penetrating as far as the hipbone or pubic bone: then that signifies a tract reaching up to there and continuing straight until not being entangled within its tortuous pathway unless towards the navel; when pain appears around this part, which ever emerges pus always without fail from it forevermore in need of medical treatment neither can solidify with ointment.
Et in istis Fistulis omnibus penetrantibus non est curatio omnino: et curatio earum est labor et uanitas ei, ex stultis medicis, super quem formatur.	And there is no cure for all fistulas in which they are involved; their treatment consists of hard work and sweating imposed by stupid doctors who fashion them. This translation retains the original Latin structure as much as possible while conveying a sense of critique or criticism found within the text, considering that such tone was often employed in historical texts when discussing medical treatments perceived to be outdated or unsuccessful.
In illa autem quae non est penetrans, et non antiqua, speratur sanatio cum serro: secundum quod ego narro tibi, et ego iam probaui: et est, ut iaceat infirmus inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et eleua crura eius usque supra coxas ipsius, et coxae eius sint inclinatae ad uentrem ipsius.	In those fistulas which are not penetrating and neither ancient nor established belief dictates a cure with surgical instruments: as I have said before now; here it is tried, but for the bedridden person to lie between your hands over his own back while straightening out legs up to their hips in the direction of urination itself. This passage describes an alternative method prescribed within this historical text that involves manual manipulation rather than invasive surgery—a common theme during times when medical understanding and technology were limited, suggesting a form of treatment predating modern medicine' enduring as some remnants even nowadays in folk practices or less conventional therapies.
Deinde intromittetentam plumbi, aut aeris, si est in Fistula tortuositas, donec scias ubi peruenit tenta.	Thereafter introduce iron or air into it if within a fistula of twisted nature until you find out where the tract has reached its end point and become apparent to sight. If then you feel that your finger has pierced through itself ascertained beyond doubt by touch alone and apart from feeling between its digit or flesh: at that time therefore you know undoubtedly that it is penetrated; for although a work of surgery (operation) should be done in the matter, since no healing was promised.
Dixerunt tamen, quia sanatur in quibusdam hominibus caro, et ex medicatione qua ei speratur iuuamentum, est, ut ignias cauterium subtile secundum amplitudinem Fistulae, sicut praecessit, et intromittas ipsum ignitum in Fistulam, donec perueniat circa anum.	They nevertheless said that it is healed in some men of flesh and by medicine thereupon hoping for improvement (healing), as kindling which has escaped into a fistula may be carefully applied with the appropriate size; place this flaming instrument inside the Fistula, until about one year passes.
Deinde itera illud bis, aut ter, donec scias, quia iam adustae sunt omnes illae carnes additae filtratae, quae sunt similes cannulae pennae auis.	Thereafter repeat that twofold or thrice; until you know, for the flesh added to all those which have been burnt are now sifted and resemble a feather-pencil.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, donec egrediantur illae carnes, quae adustae sunt: deinde cura illud cum unguentis generantibus carnem et consolidantibus.	Thereafter care for it with wax dissolved (melted), until those burnt flesh pieces come out; then the same takes place, when using ointments to renew and solidify the flesh which is burnt.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est.	If it heals therefore good will result.
Et si non, tunc non sanatur cum alia curatione unquam.	And if not then at no time shall there be any other form of curing ever used on it.
Et si egreditur tenta, et non peruenerit usque ad digitum tuum, qui est in ano, et est inter ipsum et tentam uelamen spissum ex carne, aut sifac: et uides Fistulam in eo quod sequitur superficiem cutis, tunc seca cutem ab initio Fistulae, et tu uadis secando cum tenta quod est in fistula, donec perueniat secatio ubi peruenit tentae extremitas, et liberatur tenta et cadit.	And if it escapes to be burnt and does not withstand until reaching the tip of your finger which is on its anus as well being between itself very thick from flesh or skin: then dry off that surface cutis immediately after Fistula opening, you who are a torch take care of what's within in the fistula; following this trail there will be exposed to heal through scars. Until such time when it reaches its tip where burning stopped and finally gets freed from being burnt.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas, quae assimilantur cannulae pennae auis, ut non remaneat ex eis aliquid.	Thereafter cleanse those pieces of flesh which have been burnt and sifted like a feather-pencil; so as not to remain anything from them.
Si autem uincit te sanguis, et soluit inter te et inter operationem tuam ut seces illas carnes: tunc melius quod fit, et uelocioris iuuamenti, cauterizare eam cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta.	If the blood bursts you and it separates itself from between yourself and your operation such that better results occur: then meliora facis by using cautery with fire or sharp medicine.
Quoniam cauterium cum igne aggregat habitudines bonas, adustionem illarum carnium additarum, et abscisionem sanguinis, et exiccationem humiditatum.	Since the combination of hot iron with the practice is good habits; it gives a scorching effect on their flesh and bloodletting and evacuation of moisture.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, aut caulibus tritis, donec locus emittat pus, et egrediantur illae carnes adustae in pus.	Therefore take care of it with ointments made from honey or figs paste until the place excretes pus and then they withdraw their burned flesh into that pus.
Deinde cura tunc uulnus cum unguentis consolidatiuis, generantibus carnem duram: et sunt medicinae in quibus sunt stipticitas et exiccatio.	Then take care of the wound with ointments formed solidified; and there are remedies by which they achieve dryness and evacuation.
Nam quando restaurantur, tunc iam sanatur: et non times iterationem.	For when heals up, then it is already cured: and does not need repetition anymore.
Si autem Fistula iam peruenit usque ad profundum ani, et elongatur a superfluitate corporis: tunc intromitte digitum tuum in anum, et inquire cum eo.	If the fistula has reached its end and it extends from excess body fluid; then thrust your finger into his belly to find out if he needs anything more for relief. Therefore it may heal itself: or its own flesh will elongate and the blood of that which has been cut out by the knife shall be sucked up to near a finger's length using either a tendon, or another sharpened instrument with acute ends.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas quae sunt in sectione, usque ubi potes cum perscrutatione.	Then clean those flesh pieces that are cut out until you can scrutinize them.

¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	Concerning the healing of mariners and land soldiers alike; as well as for both sailors and infantrymen such as Almirmar's men or those akin to Athenian hoplites in form and approach (akin, here implying resemblance not just to Athens but also their military style
Caput LXXXII.	Chapter LXXXII.
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	The essence of Almirmar's approach is that he only treats when the ship is round and red-colored like a bald head; and it happens throughout his body especially in the lower parts, on the legs and fingers: from which comes pain while walking.
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua. This was Albucasis's directive on treating fresh injuries, emphasizing timely intervention using natural materials available during his era before the advent of modern pharmaceutical treatments.

If the wound communicates to main body parts, then it is necessary at that time to immerse clean soft wool (lanam lenem) or rose-colored oil (oleo rosato), and place this on circular areas around where these are located between thighs. This aligns with Albucasis' method of using gentle materials like lanum for dressing injuries, providing a warm compress to promote healing in medieval Latin medical texts from the Islamic Golden Age, which influenced European medicine during that era.

Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And you know that what is out of the large intestine is easier for healing; and whatever comes from it is more difficult to heal.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	And the intestine that is called Ileon does not receive healing from a wound in it for all these reasons: and this is because of its multitude coming from outside as well as its size, and also due to the delicacy of its body structure and closeness to natural nervous network.
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	And if that which proceeds from the wound is pus, it shall be reduced according to your method of treatment, reducing both the intestine as you have done equally.
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the space has been exceeded and it is now either pus or blackish matter: then there must be bands with a thread above the place which was discolored out of that for not letting blood flow.
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	Indeed, veins and arteries are involved in it.

Therefore concerning what is beyond that ligament, place two ends of the thread hanging down from the lower part outside itself: so it will be attracted to you and extracted out by means of a bladder-induced wound at its location for pus discharge.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Remember the ulcer that occurred in the intestine.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When an ulcer occurs in the intestine and it is narrowed or closed off with pus, then possible to restore it for certain people: because I have seen who was wounded inside his own belly by a lance blow, having been affected on one side of the stomach and being old wound; there also formed Fistula in that place where from hunger emerged emptiness as well as urination.
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	Therefore I gave him care for healing, until the point that it is not delicate anymore and has been restored as well-healed in place.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	After I had found the place firmly established, I feared for the weak one that came upon a weakness inherent to him himself: and it did not happen that evil emerged from this occurrence of ill health in his own body.
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And it remained within better dispositions of his own: feeding and drinking at intervals came with him outdostatic to repose; he took baths therein by night and went forth into proper food during the day.
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And some of the experimental ones said that when one happens upon a worm and is puny (ill), then it should be tied according to this way.
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And there are large ants with great heads like you take in.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then gather two weak lips (wounds), and place one ant on them which have an open mouth over the said wound pair of both strong legs, as you would for bees with their stings in these places to avoid further harm being done by biting out or eating away at those areas.
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	So that when they stand over it and bite their own mouth shut, the head still sticks to itself because they do not let go of each other's heads firmly attached together by biting down on them so as to prevent further damage being done at those places where two weak legs are joined.
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then place another ant near the first one and do not cease doing so until each wound is completely covered by a number of ants equivalent to the total size of all weak legs being treated, as for bees with their stings in these places to prevent further harm from being done.
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then he reduced it (sickness) and its wound was also taken care of.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	For that reason the heads of those remain affixed to their intestines until they are fed and restored healthy for them not so as a punishment would make an ill person worse by causing additional harm in his or her own body.
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And it is also possible that the entrails and their threadlike contents are tied together with a fine string so as to remove them from within animals: for they have been extracted by inserting this thin substance into something liquid current, after which he extracts his own intestine once inserted in like manner.
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And it is as follows that you receive this child's bowel from inside and treat it with great care.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Thereafter, tie the unspooled end of his thread at its tip.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then insert that thread into the bowels now and follow it through.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Thereafter, reduce its size within this wound.
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And such a way of surgery with flies and the bowel, therein lies nothing but according to faith in God' endurance and hope for mankind.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	Know this as well; there is a serious matter if it is found to be large and abundant especially within the small intestine: then neither wit nor skill suffices for his cure at all. If there is a fistula of such depth that it does not reach the places I have mentioned: and you hope for its healing through cure, or by urine passing to acquire knowledge about it; then take an instrument made of metal (iron) if the Fistula follows rectitude, and inquire into it with itself.

When gangrene occurs to some of the body's muscles due to cold exposure (hypothermia), and this area is extended; subsequently it either rises up or pierces through: afterward what exists in that part comes out as if its sole purpose was for discharge, leaving behind a clean space almost like an empty womb. Because the parts of this craft and its distin0ncee's are not comprehended by narration: nor does it understand that book, but a prudent artificer compares little with much to know; and finds himself at home in both cases—when things occur within his land and when they do so without him. Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that arrows do not come out from limbs where they are fixed except in two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	But by the attractive force of a certain place into which it was placed.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or alternatively, from another party's opposite side.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And those that go out are either due to being attracted into a part of the body where they were placed and which is drawn by an arrows' elasticity; or because it follows from its own nature and does not need any external assistance for this action, as when piercing something.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	That which does not obey the command to exit at the appointed hour falls; then it is necessary that you let go of some days and allow its decaying body within itself until only putrefaction remains: by whose attraction will your arrow continue to be drawn back, thus completing the cycle.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if a figure is in the bone and does not obey your command to exit, then you must also let go of some days for that too; allowing its return due to constant movement with all attraction every day until it eventually emerges again.

That which does not obey your command to exit after a day; then it is necessary that you pierce the surrounding area of the arrow within all parts of bone with very fine stakes until they are sufficiently expanded.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Thereafter draw her out by its attraction and extract it from itself.

¶ De uena Cephalica.	About the Headache.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	If headaches are felt (Pain in the Head), then sucking blood from the head is recommended treatment because it draws out blood from the head and relieves eye diseases.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is recommended in this pain itself that one should draw blood from the wound with oil or a purgative myrtle mixture: for salt is universal solvent of all pains (of drawing out blood), since it does not contain artery, nor nerve; and therefore nothing can happen to you.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	But nevertheless you will find yourself satisfied by blood-letting (phlebotomy), such as when one draws a single drop of blood from an ass's neck and feels more comfortable: and it does not harm if the place is found without first percussing with bare hands, but then drawing off some bleeding again at intervals.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo. In wound there is an initial superficial draining of blood and fluid from it; afterwards a thorough examination for the removal of thickened blood should be done carefully, delicately, but thoroughly with precision instruments such as scalpels or scissors. This process may require several attempts to completely evacuate all grossly accumulated clots without causing undue harm to surrounding tissues and ensuring minimal bleeding during each intervention for optimal healing conditions post-surgery.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is foul and putrid, then a third scarring should be done accordingly to achieve final healing outcomes as well for ensuring complete removal of infected areas from surgical interventions which would otherwise risk further complications if not thoroughly treated with appropriate antiseptic measures.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una. This approach signifies an understanding that careful, controlled measures in medical interventions

To safely achieve this level without causing further damage requires precision and understanding of wound characteristics.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What should be administered using oil as per the place of Ventosarius that prevents excessive bleeding? In ancient medicine practices such as those documented by Albucasis and his contemporaries in Arabic texts like "Al-Tasrif li-madani fi al-‘ulum al-tab'ini," treatments often included plant oils, which were known for their healing
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In that case where the cut is hard, dark, and porous with strict fissures in it, as Ventosarius instructs to be anointed using oil kept opened for usage, soothingly warmed up or cooled down; if during summer time (i.e., when heat prevails), then let us use olive oil that is fresh and strong-smelling, like unguentur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis: si est in tempore aestatis ut sic erat indicandum sub scriptis - with warmed up or cooled down olives. If instead of oil we should use the essence derived from wormwood leaves (alkeiri), pomegranate juice (uiolatum) or honey made from cucurbitae seeds (dulcibus amygdalis). These substances are traditionally believed to possess antibacterial and healing properties, which can aid in reducing the risk of contamination due to porous wounds.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is during winter time, then Narcissus oil, or oil of the hyacinth, or chamomile oil, or lavender (Sarbabint), and similar things to these...
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	And if it is overly thick and cold, then Frankincense oil or myrrh oil or saffron (Anethol) oil...
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	And if it is moist and warm to the skin of these young ones' tender flesh: then it must be that no oil (must not) be applied and after bathing they should be rinsed off with water rosy, or chilled water, or spring water, or cucumber water, or Portulacum ear liquid things...
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	And if his blood contains much moisture, wash him with flowing waters mixed with vinegar or water of Myrtle and Sumac...
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	And if his swellings are overly thick and heavy, then wash them with flowing waters mixed with old wine or water of Sambalacum (salsa), or boiled Samouci herb, or decoction Anetlli flowers...
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas. Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it should not be that he sleeps after a bathing session.

Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is necessary that he should drink more days' water than food; and must also have in the pot some wine with vinegar for diarrhoea or phlebotomy purposes: let him take at least a spoonful into those pots where certain men are cooking salted meat, or medicinal herbs of muscary (musk). And before venesection; and after. Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And must not have that any one of them enter into the vessel heated.

Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	Then they are pressed, for when they feel something from the blood, they instantly stick to it.
