¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	Book Three of the Surgical Works by Albucasis.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	A lecture on restoration and detachment, as well as curing twists and similar issues.
Caput I.	Chapter One: On the Curing of Twisted
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	This Chapter is also frequently necessary for Medicine and concerns itself with the restoration of a broken bone or joint displacement due to an injury.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	But know this: those who from ignorance of these matters and the ancient texts will attempt to treat with twisted bodies or joints without understanding them at all. They have not examined such a book ever since its composition in antiquity, nor read even one letter written by Albucasis himself on the matter for years.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	And due to this reason, that method of treatment from such people has been kept secret here among us.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	And I never benefited from it in any way and did not understand that which was adept only due to the length of lectures on ancient medical texts books and a study over their intelligence until when came forth my knowledge thereof outside them by Albucasis himself, as written here before me.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	Then I proceeded to test the sticky substance and studied its duration on myself (meaning that it is not harmful). This was done after hearing, firsthand through personal experience
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	And now I have described to you all the content contained within this chapter which includes my knowledge: and after shortening that experiment of mine for your benefit (meaning not harmful), having finished with its length reduction, immediately ceased reducing it further; then showing by signs at last when reduced enough declination is stopped. And in this I formed many shapes like instruments used therein being an addition to the variation of direction as done previously also on two occasions beforehand in previous chapters (these have not been lost but are available for reading here).
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	The sum of all collections and compilations concerning the treatment for bone fractures from which initial step is required before we begin recounting the details of individual or diverse fractures:
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	Let us begin this chapter with an introduction that sets the stage for our discourse on surgery: we should first have everyone know and understand - especially to those quick at heart - how beneficial it is in maintaining health and curing illnesses, particularly by treating ear ailments.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	Hence I say that whenever a person suffers from fractures or dislocations, twists, or other incidents affecting the body' energy balance, as soon as this happens: then it is necessary to address first of all by phlebotomy and proper treatment - either simultaneously. If there are obstructions in healing like a weak constitution due to vices; if that individual has experienced something from these instances before such age or oldness where the body becomes decrepit, as when one gets ill during intense heat without rest:
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Be content with your food, fruits and meats; but abstain from wine, fatty meats, and to repay the body anything that fills it up with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	When securely fixed in the hot clasp of disease and not allowed to pour its substance into your flesh, then let the weak return once more unto their own custom first with which they used themselves as regimen.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	Therefore when the broken bone begins to heal, it is necessary that its food be strengthened by much fatty and wholesome nutrition; with which there should be sweetness of taste: as are man'in diet from boiled wheat cooked in water together with rice, barley, chickpeas (fava beans), lentils, dates palm sap, honey, fishes and recently caught freshwater animals. And wine mustered up large; likewise of those things mentioned above for food: as were the meals prepared from boiled wheat cooked in water together with rice, barley, chickpeas (fava beans), lentils, dates palm sap, honey, fishes and recently caught freshwater animals.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	Hence in that diet also the blood clotting of a broken bone will be better achieved.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	And I know that the broken bones of men who are old and decrepit at heart cannot be strengthened and continued according to their own nature always because of an outflow from them: therefore they continue as in infancy, like children's ribcages after removal of flesh.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	Nevertheless the nature of a broken bone attaches itself to something similar from all parts with which it has some glue-like substance: because this is hardness and adhesion; until they are melted down together into one, and bound unto each other. Then will grow in firmness and strength just as was the first time when nothing forbade him anything of his operations except for food given to infirmities with which there should be taste sweetness, full nutrition, fatty contentment, something like honey; until they are melted into one, bound unto each other: from this cause is it necessary that we place in the feeding of weak bones such nourishments as contain great weightiness and a certain thickness. And therefore I have spoken thus much about breaking bones for strengthening them, just to explain what should be done by food with which they will grow firm and strong again through these means until it is melted together into one after the first time when nothing forbade him anything of his operations excepting this: so that he may recover health.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And you know, that there are different types of fractures according to the nature of the limbs; for a crural (leg) fracture is quite different from a skull (cranial) bone fracture: and a pectoral (chest) bone fracture differs from a dorsal (backbone) fracture, just as all other remaining limbs also differ according to their own specific types. Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	And there are different kinds of bone fractures themselves as well.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	Because it is a curved (or arched) fracture, apart from the fact that such events may occur on ships at sea.

¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	The mode of emplastrum that heals a broken bone.

Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	This entire preparation according to the heat of the part and calmness it brings in response to that warmth.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem. ¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	The mode of plaster that confers pain relief is used for the injury.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	Prepare the mixture by grinding mugwort and chickpeas with parts of hamstring tendons or quills of a bird's penis (if available), as well as other ingredients such as elderberries, honeycombs, bone fragments, salt, etc. Mix thoroughly until smooth: then apply this paste to the wound area and let it set there.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	The quantity must be prepared in such measure that the binding remains intact; then it is removed, and if there does not appear to occur any weakness of feeling or pain, neither pricking nor inflammation of the fractured bone at its place: only after several days should you remove this.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	If itching or pain occurs at the place of application; if anxiety is present due to pain, or swelling appears: then immediately apply warmth and remove that for some time during the day while applying this ointment directly from its container on a clean cloth with which you can easily replace when needed. Take in hand either woollen pancloth (if available), soft sponge dampened down, moistened fabric or even seaweed: and submerge it into hot water; then apply the warm compress to that place while removing any remaining ointment from there until quieting of discomfort occurs.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	Thereafter, release the limb for one hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	Afterward place the limb above a warm cloth soaked in vinegar and oil (or rose-colored oil), submerging it there: tie over that securely one night until sure not to slip off with hot discomfort, when then stops inflammation of the member's part as well removes pain.

¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	Regarding restoration, when a nose is broken or fractured.

Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas. Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	If indeed the fracture is on two parts; then do so likewise for both and immediately restore it after each break if possible within a day.

¶ De restauratione Anchae.	On restoration of those things, (such as in a treatment process).

Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc cessa ab extensione eius, et ipsius restauratione, donec sedetur apostema calidum: et pone super ipsum quod sedet ipsum, secundum quod praecessit, deinde redi ad restaurationem eius: et stringe ipsum sicut oportet.	If then he suffers from a hot ulcer; cease stretching him and his repair until such time as the heat subsides of its own accord or is relieved by something else, either way that it stops being an ulcer: after which place one above what remains underneath soaked in cold water taken previously. If thereafter he suffers from another hot ulcer; again cease stretching him and his repair until such time as the heat subsides of its own accord or is relieved by something else, either way that it stops being an ulcer: after which place one above what remains underneath soaked in cold water taken previously. ¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	On treating displacement of fingers (Digitorum).
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX on the topic of 'Displacement

¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	On curing of spinal disc herniation:
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When it happens to someone that the vertebrae or neck are out of place completely; or when they have dislocated multiple spondylia from their usual locations; then there is no treatment for them because death properly ensues.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And it is a sign that their poverty comes out of themselves without willingness; and often they are softened from some part of his body, or two legs, arms or shoulders of the same person, or one limb taken away: or sometimes only the spondylia are removed.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	Indeed often they remove them that frequently happen removal to four parts.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	Therefore those which are removed from the backside it is called Prognathism.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	Therefore the treatment for such is considered at that time if Prognathism occurs during childhood; then there is no treatment for it and certainly not salvation from its evil effects.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.
